questions.question_text: A technician must manually modify the HOSTS system file in order to resolve a website address to a specified local destination. Which of the following utilities should the technician use to BEST accomplish the task?

discussion.content: Click File in the menu bar at the top of Notepad and select Open. Browse the Windows Hosts File location: C:\Windows\System32\Drivers\etc and open the hosts file. Make the needed changes, as shown above, and close Notepad. Save when prompted.
Notepad is incredibly useful for modifying all sorts of plain text files. Host, Config, .bat, HTML/CSS/PHP/JS/XML, registry and licensing files etc. I've used it a lot for various things.

Notepad can contain commands/scripts. "A script is generally targetted at completing a specific task, whether that task is based within a web-based application or is used by a net admin to perform a repetitive administrative task" - The Official CompTIA A+ Core 2 Guide
Notepad is the best app to use in this case.

comments.content:
The hosts file maps hostnames to IP addresses and is stored as a plain text file. Therefore the best way to edit that is via a text editor like notepad.

You can see it by going to run and typing: notepad c:\windows\system32\drivers\etc\hosts
Editing configuration files is easily done in notepad or notepad++

discussion.content:
Best answer is D
Explanation: The best option here is to create alerts to let any and all administrators know if a backup failure occures. These alerts would either be created at the network-attached storage (NAS) device or at the individual servers to be backed up. If and admin receives an alert, that person will know to either rerun the back up or (more likely) fix the backup task and the run it. One of the issues here is that you might not know if a backup fails- without the alerts, that is.
Incorrect answers: Setting up scripts is good for the backup processes themselves, but you first need to be alerted to an issue before you can script a rerun of the failed backup. In this case, the backups are being stored to a NAS device (on the LAN), so they are not being stored offsite. You should always test a backup the first time it runs and periodically afterwards; however, frequent restoration tests are very time-consuming, not to mention hardware-intensive to the NAS device. Restoring to VM is a good way to test, but it's not good way to ensure rapid recovery, nor is it where the backups are supposed to be restored to; the question says "physical servers."
CompTIA A+ Practice Questions Exam Cram Core 1 and Core 2
